trans-unit.source: Provides the capability to group controls together.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
A form represents the outermost grouping of controls within an ASP.NET mobile Web page.
An individual mobile Web page can contain multiple forms at the outermost level.
Forms cannot be nested; use <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Panel> controls if you want to nest containers.
For more information, see [Introduction to the Form Control](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/24a1946a-bb3c-41c8-90cd-f00643525016).

To display a specific form, either set the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobilePage.ActiveForm%2A> property on the current page to the desired form, or set the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Link.NavigateUrl%2A> property in a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Link> control to the desired form.
You can include literal text along with its accompanying markup tags in the text contents of the Form control.
When using templates, it is important to remember that the Form control creates instances of templates in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.OnInit%2A> method for the form.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.OnInit%2A> method for the form is called before `Page_Load` and `Page_Init`.
Also, the page constructor executes too early to set templates in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.OnInit%2A> method because the form is not yet created.
To correct this, hook the form's own <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.OnInit%2A> method, and create an instance of the template there.
For more information, see [Implementing Templated Rendering](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/b86d9d1d-ab18-4cad-a825-092826bb3922).
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form"></xref> class.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Gets or sets the URL to which the form is submitted.
The default value is an empty string ("").
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The default value, an empty string (""), causes postbacks to the page containing the current form.
You can override the default value to submit the form to a different URL.
> [!NOTE] > If the Action property is inherited, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control posts form contents to the inherited URL.
The URL to which the form is submitted.
Occurs when a form becomes active.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The Activate event occurs under the following circumstances: - When a page is first requested, the first form is activated.
- When the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobilePage.ActiveForm%2A> property of the page is set programmatically.
- When the user navigates to a form through a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Link> control whose target is a form.
This event's position in the event chain makes it very important for binding child controls to data sources or for setting a form property that can be inherited by all child controls.
To be added.
Gets or sets a property that determines whether an additional trailing break is rendered after the control.
This break causes subsequent content to start on the next line.
The default is <xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This property is ignored by the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form> control.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if an additional trailing break is rendered after the control; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
The property was read at design time.
-or- An attempt was made to set the property.
Gets or sets the control on the form that can be paginated.
The default is <xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref> (<xref uid="langword_csharp_Nothing" name="Nothing" href=""></xref> in Visual Basic).
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The ControlToPaginate property is used to allow a single control on a form to paginate its contents across several views on mobile devices and providing next and previous navigation between views.
A control can paginate its contents even if a containing <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Panel> control has its <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Panel.Paginate%2A> property set to `false`.
The control on the form that can be paginated.
Called by device adapters to create the default templated user interface (UI) for the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Set to true if the instantiated templates must bind to available data (which usually happens on the first request).
Set to false if the templates must not bind to data, and instead rely on view state to fill them in (which usually happens on subsequent postbacks).
Gets or sets the index of the current page in the active form.
The default value is <xref uid="langword_csharp_0" name="0" href=""></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This property is used for form pagination.
The index of the current page in the active form.
Occurs when an active form becomes inactive.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
A form becomes inactive under the following circumstances: - When the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobilePage.ActiveForm%2A> property of the page is programmatically set to another form.
- When the user navigates to a form through a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Link> control whose target is a form.
If neither of these actions occurs, the active form will never receive a Deactivate event.
This event's position in the event chain makes it very important in resetting the child controls, data set, or global variables.
To be added.
Returns a panel that represents the footer for the form.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Panel"></xref> that represents the footer for the form.
Returns a set of forms that are linked to the current form.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
When a form contains navigation elements that activate another form without interacting with the server, it is considered to be a linked form.
There are several factors involved for a form to be considered linked.

For example, if the following three stipulations are met, Form B is considered to be one of the forms linked to Form A: - Form A contains a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Link> control with its destination as Form B. - Form A does not contain an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.OnDeactivate%2A> event handler.
- Form B has no <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.OnActivate%2A> event handler.
The distinction is the set of all forms that do not require server interactions to transfer control between.
The total weight for the target device of the resulting linked forms must not exceed (used in pagination).
If its value is -1, the total weight will not be considered when linked forms are added to the list.
A set of forms that are linked to the current form.
Returns <xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the form has a handler for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Activate"></xref> event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the form has a handler for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Activate"></xref> event; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Returns <xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Deactivate"></xref> event exists.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Deactivate"></xref> event exists; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Returns a panel that represents the header for the form.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Panel"></xref> that represents the header for the form.
Loads View State from a private source.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Current view state of the control.
Gets or sets the method used to submit the form.
The default value is <xref uid="langword_csharp_post" name="post" href=""></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
A `get` request is limited in the amount of data it can post.
Some types of postbacks might fail when using a `get` request.
The advantage of a `get` request is that all the parameters are specified as part of the URL, and the URL can be cached or saved.
The elements of a `post` request are contained within the <xref:System.Web.HttpRequest.Form%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
The method used to submit the form.
Called when the form is activated.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The default implementation raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Activate> event.
Inheriting classes can override this method to perform other tasks when the form is activated.
An object defined by the <xref:System.EventArgs> object that contains event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.DataBinding"></xref> event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
An <xref uid="langword_csharp_EventArgs" name="EventArgs" href=""></xref> object that contains the event data.
Called when the form is activated.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The default implementation raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Deactivate> event.
Inheriting classes can override this method to perform other tasks when the form is deactivated.
An object defined by an <xref:System.EventArgs> object that contains event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.Init"></xref> event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
When notified by this method, server controls must perform any initialization steps that are required to create and set up an instance.
In this stage of the server control's lifecycle, the control's view state has yet to be populated.
Additionally, you cannot access other server controls when this method is called either, regardless of whether it is a child or parent to this control.
Other server controls are not certain to be created and ready for access.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> object that contains the event data.
The form is contained by another form.
Occurs when a form is paginated.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> object that contains event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.PreRender"></xref> event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
An EventArgs object that contains the event data.
Returns the number of pages in the form after the form is paginated.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form> control exposes the PageCount property and the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.CurrentPage%2A> property, which provide information about how the current form is paginated.
The PageCount property also helps provide navigation capability to another page.

For example, when rendering on a richer device, a search results form might include device-specific UI elements that allow the user to browse to a page of results by number rather than by link navigation.
> [!NOTE] > This value is available after the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Paginated> event has occurred.
To get the PageCount property, you can handle the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.Paginated> event of the form.
The number of pages in the form after the form is paginated.
Gets or sets the style used to render the form's pagination UI.
The default value is an empty string ("").
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
If this property is set programmatically, it is not persisted for each request.
If the property is set declaratively, the property is persisted for each request.
The style used to render the form's pagination UI.
Returns whether or not the children of the control must be paginated.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the children of the control must be paginated; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Occurs when a form is paginated.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
A form is paginated prior to rendering each request.
After pagination is complete, the Paginated event occurs.
After this event occurs, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.CurrentPage%2A> property of the form contains the actual number of pages for the form.
To be added.
Paginates the control and its children.
Called internally by ASP.NET.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The pager.
Notifies the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form"></xref> object of a postback event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
A <xref:System.String> that represents an optional event argument to be passed to the event handler.
Sends server control content to a provided <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter"></xref> object, which writes the content to be rendered on the client.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Writes markup characters and text to an output stream.
Saves any private view-state changes that have occurred since the page was loaded from persistence.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
An object containing the altered private view state.
Returns the panel that contains any device-specific script for the form, if a script template has been defined and chosen for the target device.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The panel that contains any device-specific script for the form.
For a description of this member, see <xref:System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler.RaisePostBackEvent%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This member is an explicit interface member implementation.
It can be used only when the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form> instance is cast to an <xref:System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler> interface.
A <xref:System.String> that represents an optional event argument to be passed to the event handler.
Gets or sets the title of the specified form.
The default value is an empty <xref uid="langword_csharp_string" name="string" href=""></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
For devices that support a title separate from the page content, you can render the title as part of the form.
The title can be rendered as part of the form, on devices that support a title separate from page content (for example, on the title bar of a browser using the title tag in HTML).
